title: Collisions - colliding blocks and exploding carts

content.question:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A group of students has two blocks, Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and Block <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>. Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> has a known mass <math alttext="m sub A equals 0.100 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.100</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>kg</mi></math>. Block <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> is more massive than Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>, but its mass <math alttext="m sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></msub></math> is unknown. The students wish to experimentally determine <math alttext="m sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></msub></math>.

As shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, the students have a long, horizontal track along which the blocks can slide. Friction between the track and the blocks is negligible. The students have two photogates which can measure the speed of a cart at a certain position, but no other motion-sensing equipment.

(a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data that would allow the students to determine the value of <math alttext="m sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></msub></math> by making a linear graph. Provide enough detail so that the experiment could be replicated, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

frqParts.text:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A group of students has two blocks, Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and Block <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>. Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> has a known mass <math alttext="m sub A equals 0.100 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.100</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>kg</mi></math>. Block <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> is more massive than Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>, but its mass <math alttext="m sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></msub></math> is unknown. The students wish to experimentally determine <math alttext="m sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></msub></math>.

As shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, the students have a long, horizontal track along which the blocks can slide. Friction between the track and the blocks is negligible. The students have two photogates which can measure the speed of a cart at a certain position, but no other motion-sensing equipment.

(a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data that would allow the students to determine the value of <math alttext="m sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></msub></math> by making a linear graph. Provide enough detail so that the experiment could be replicated, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

(b) For the data collected in the procedure from part (a), describe how the students could create a linear graph and how that graph could be used to determine the value of <math alttext="m sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></msub></math>.

The following day the students are given two carts, Cart <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and Cart <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. Carts <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> have masses <math alttext="m sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="m sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, respectively, both of which are unknown. The students wish to determine the mass <math alttext="m sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> of Cart <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.
They also have a collection of blocks that are identical to Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>, each with a known mass <math alttext="m sub A equals 0.100 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.100</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>kg</mi></math>, which can be attached to Cart <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. A spring attached to the inside of Cart <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> can be compressed and used to launch the carts in opposite directions, as indicated.
The students conduct a number of experimental trials in which the number of blocks attached to Cart <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is varied. For each trial the carts are pressed together, compressing the spring, and then released. The speeds <math alttext="v sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="v sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> of carts <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, respectively, are experimentally determined after the carts are released from rest. The table shows the results of the experiment.
Number of Blocks<math alttext="v sub 1, in meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mpadded><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mtext>m/s</mtext></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math><math alttext="v sub 2, in meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mtext>m/s</mtext></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math><math alttext="0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn></math><math alttext="2.20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.20</mn></math><math alttext="1.06" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.06</mn></math><math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math><math alttext="1.50" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.50</mn></math><math alttext="1.35" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.35</mn></math><math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math><math alttext="1.17" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.17</mn></math><math alttext="1.38" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.38</mn></math><math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math><math alttext="0.94" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.94</mn></math><math alttext="1.52" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.52</mn></math><math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math><math alttext="0.77" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.77</mn></math><math alttext="1.60" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.60</mn></math>Note: <math alttext="m sub A equals 0.100 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.100</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>kg</mi></math>
(c)
The students correctly determine that the relationship between <math alttext="v sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="v sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="m sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> is given by: <math alttext="the fraction v sub 2, end sub, over v sub 1, end sub, equals the fraction m sub 1, end sub, over m sub 2, end sub, plus the fraction with numerator N m sub A, end sub, and denominator m sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>N</mi><msub><mi>m</mi><mi>A</mi></msub></mrow><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mfrac></math>, where <math alttext="N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>N</mi></math> is the number of blocks attached to Cart <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The students create a graph with <math alttext="the fraction v sub 2, end sub, over v sub 1, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mfrac></math> plotted on the vertical axis.

i. Indicate which measured or calculated quantity could be plotted on the horizontal axis to yield a linear graph whose slope can be used to calculate an experimental value for the mass <math alttext="m sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> of Block <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. You may use the remaining columns in the table, as needed, to record any quantities (including units) that are not already in the table.

Vertical axis:    <math alttext="the fraction v sub 2, end sub, over v sub 1, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mfrac></math>              Horizontal axis: __________

ii. On the grid in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part (c)(i). Clearly scale and label the horizontal axis, including units.

iii. Draw a straight best-fit line for the data graphed in part (c)(ii).

(d) Calculate an experimental value for the mass of Block <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, <math alttext="m sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, using the best-fit line that you drew in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> in part (c)(iii).

skill.text: 1.B: Create quantitative graphs with appropriate scales and units, including plotting data.
